title: Walt Bond
text:
Walter Franklin Bond (October 19, 1937 – September 14, 1967) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> player who appeared in six <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> seasons between and for the <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a>, <a href="Houston%20Astros">Houston Colt .45s/Astros</a> and <a href="Minnesota%20Twins">Minnesota Twins</a>. An <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> and <a href="first%20baseman">first baseman</a>, he played the last five seasons of his 11-year professional career after being diagnosed with <a href="leukemia">leukemia</a> while serving in the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> in 1962. The disease finally took Bond's life in the closing weeks of the baseball season — a year during which he had made the <a href="1967%20Minnesota%20Twins%20season">Twins' roster</a> coming out of <a href="spring%20training">spring training</a>.
The native of <a href="Denmark%2C%20Tennessee">Denmark, Tennessee</a>, attended <a href="Lane%20College">Lane College</a>; he stood tall and weighed , threw right-handed and batted left-handed. With his imposing size, he was an effective power hitter who also batted for <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">average</a> (.299) during his minor league career, and brief <a href="Negro%20leagues">Negro leagues</a> career with the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Monarchs">Kansas City Monarchs</a>. In 1962, the year of his diagnosis, Bond batted .320 in 132 games for the <a href="Salt%20Lake%20City%20Bees">Salt Lake City Bees</a> of the Triple-A <a href="Pacific%20Coast%20League">Pacific Coast League</a>. Then, in a 12-game September stint with the Indians, Bond hit six <a href="home%20runs">home runs</a> in only 50 <a href="at%20bats">at bats</a>, drove in 17 <a href="runs%20batted%20in">runs</a>, batted .380 and <a href="slugging%20percentage">slugged</a> .800. Yet he could not make the 1963 Indians roster and spent that campaign in Triple-A.
On December 19, 1963, he was acquired by Houston. The Colt .45s' <a href="general%20manager%20%28baseball%29">general manager</a>, <a href="Paul%20Richards%20%28baseball%29">Paul Richards</a>, was aware of Bond's illness, but the team doctor examined Bond and determined that the leukemia was in remission. Bond then turned in his best Major League season as the starting first baseman for the <a href="1964%20Houston%20Colt%20.45s%20season">1964 Colt .45s</a>, leading Houston in home runs (20) and runs batted in (85), and appearing in 148 <a href="games%20played">games</a>. The following year, Bond held onto his starting job, but his production slumped with the team's move into the <a href="Astrodome">Astrodome</a>; some teammates later speculated that his leukemia had recurred that season, affecting his play. Sent to the Twins just before the season, he returned to Triple-A and batted .316 with 18 home runs in 122 games for the <a href="Denver%20Bears">Denver Bears</a>, earning an invitation to spring training for 1967.
Bond made the team and batted .313 in part-time duty during the season's first month. But the Twins released him on May 15, and although Bond caught on with the <a href="Jacksonville%20Suns">Jacksonville Suns</a>, his declining health forced him to the sidelines after only three games. He entered a <a href="Houston%2C%20Texas">Houston</a> hospital for treatment, but died there at age 29. Said his physician, Dr. Hatch Cummings: "He showed the strength of character and will that only champions possess. It was an exhibition of courage, and in the best tradition of baseball."
Bond's 307 big-league hits included 40 <a href="double%20%28baseball%29">doubles</a>, 11 <a href="triple%20%28baseball%29">triples</a> and 41 homers.
